facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from the order of the High Court of judicature at Bombay passed on September 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the order of the High Court of judicature at Bombay passed on September 22, 1955, on a reference under section 66 (1) of the Indian Income-tax Act XI of 1922

facts.text: The High Court answered the question of law referred to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter referred to as the said Act made by the Income- tax Appellate Tribunal whereby the High Court answered the question of law referred to it by the Tribunal in the affirmative.

facts.text: The respondent was an employee of Dadajee Dhackjee and Co., Bombay, hereinafter referred to as the firm.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was an employee of Dadajee Dhackjee and Co., Bombay hereinafter referred to as the firm . The firm used to pay to each of its three employees, including the respondent, a commission

facts.text: The firm used to pay to each of its three employees, including the respondent, a commission of one per cent on its total annual turnover in its Colour Department in addition to their respective salaries.

anchor.surface_text: The firm used to pay to each of its three employees, including the respondent, a commission of one per cent. On its total annual turnover in its Colour Department in addition to their respective salaries.

facts.text: Assessment year 1945-46, for which the accounting year was Sambat 2000 corresponding to the period between October 30, 1943, to October 17, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In connection with the assessment of the firms income for the assessment year 1945-46, for which the accounting year was Sambat 2000 corresponding the period between October 30, 1943, to October 17, 1944

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer found that the profit and loss account of the Colour Department of the firm had been debited with Rs. 84,540 as commission paid to three employees including the respondent, calculated at three per cent on the annual turnover.

anchor.surface_text: , the Income-tax Officer found that the profit and loss account of the Colour Department of the firm had been debited with Rs. 84,540 as and by way of commission pad to three employees of the firm including the respondent, the commission being calculated at three per cent.

facts.text: In the preceding accounting year, Sambat 1999, and assessment year 1944-45, the Income Tax Officer allowed only one per cent commission on total annual turnover as reasonable under Section 10(2)(xv) and disallowed the balance of two per cent.

anchor.surface_text: On the annual turnover of that department, i.e., at one per cent in respect of each of the per cent. to those three employees in the preceding accounting year., Sambat 1999, and in the assessment for the corresponding assessment year 1944-45 the Income Tax Officer had allowed only one per cent.

facts.text: For assessment year 1945-46, Income Tax Officer allowed Rs. 28,180 being commission at one per cent as reasonable and disallowed the balance Rs. 56,360.

anchor.surface_text: commission on the total annual turnover of the Colour Department as a, reasonable and permissible deduction under Section 10 (2) (xv) and disallowed the bal-lance of two per cent. commission actually paid by the firm in that year. As, according to him, the same condition obtained in the assessment year 1945-46, he allowed Rupees 28,180

facts.text: Share of each of the three employees in the amount disallowed in Sambat year 2000 worked out at Rs. 18,787.

anchor.surface_text: being commission at one per cent. as reasonable and disallowed the balance amounting to Rs. 56,360. Thus the share of each of the three employees in the amount disallowed in Sambat year 2000 worked out at Rs. 18,787.

facts.text: Profit of Colour Department shown as Rs. 4,27,139 raised to Rs. 5,30,900 by adding back Rs. 56,360 disallowed commission and certain other sums.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the profit of the Colour Department shown as Rs. 4,27,139 in the Profit and Loss account of that Department for Sambat 2000 was raised from that figure to Rs. 5,30,900 by adding back Rs. 56,360 which was disallowed out of Rs. 84,540 paid to the employees

facts.text: Reason for disallowance: amount paid as commission was to the extent of 2/3 thereof unreasonable and excessive, not permissible under Section 10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: as and by way of commission and certain other sums which we need number specify or discuss. The reason given for this disallowance was that the amount paid as commission was to the extent of 2/3 thereof, unreasonable and excessive, and number permissible under Section 10 (2) (xv) .

facts.text: After deducting Rs. 1,19,816 loss of Motor Department from Rs. 5,30,900 profit of Colour Department, total income of firm computed at Rs. 4,11,084.

anchor.surface_text: After deducting Rs. 1,19,816 being the loss of the Motor Department from the profit of Rs. 5,30,900 of the Colour Department, so arrived at, the total income of the firm was computed at Rs. 4,11,084.

facts.text: Firm was registered under Section 26A, no demand made on firm per Section 23(5)(a), total income distributed amongst two partners who were husband and wife.

anchor.surface_text: As the firm was registered under Section 26A of the said Act, numberdemand was made on the firm in view of Section 23 (5) (a) and the total income computed as aforesaid was distributed amongst the two partners who were husband and wife.

facts.text: Wife's share included in total income of husband under Section 16(3)(i).

anchor.surface_text: As the wifes share is to be included in the total income of the husband under Section 16 3 (1) , the entire income of the firm was taken into consideration in the assessment of the male partner.

facts.text: Business of firm taken over by private limited company Dadajee Dhackjee and Co. Ltd. as going concern with assets and liabilities from Sambat year 2001.

anchor.surface_text: the Income Tax Officer next considered the claim of the firm for relief under Section 25 (4) of the said Act, as the business of the firm had been taken over by a private limited company, Dadajee Dhackjee and Co. Ltd.,

facts.text: Notice given on June 4, 1945 about discontinuance of business.

anchor.surface_text: as a going concern with its assets and liabilities from the Sambat year 2001. As the firm had been assessed under the Income-tax Act, 1918 and as notice was duly given on June 4, 1945 about the discontinuance of the business,

facts.text: Income Tax Officer allowed relief under Section 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: the Income Tax Officer held that the firm was entitled to the relief claimed and accordingly allowed the same.

facts.text: Respondent submitted returns on March 19, 1949 for assessment years 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19,1949, the respondent submitted returns for the assessment years 1944-45, 1945-46,1946-47, 1947-48 and 1948-49.

facts.text: Respondent claimed exemption from income-tax and super-tax on commission disallowed to firm (Rs. 18,787 for 1945-46) based on Finance Department Notification No. 878-F dated March 21, 1922 as amended by No. 8 dated March 24, 1928.

anchor.surface_text: In connection with the assessment years 1944-45 and 1945-46, the respondent claimed that, as in the assessment of the firm during the years 1944-45 and 1945-46 two-thirds of the commission paid to him for Sambat years 1999 and 2000 had been disallowed and taxed in the hands of the firm, he was entitled to an exemption

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the claim, upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected this claim and his decision was upheld on appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. A further appeal to the Tribunal was also rejected,

facts.text: Tribunal on January 14, 1955 submitted statement of case to High Court under section 66(1) raising question: Whether the assessee is entitled to relief granted by the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: On application under section 66 (1) of the said Act, the Tribunal, on January 14, 1955, submitted a statement of case to the High Court raising the following question of law for the determination of the High Court

facts.text: High Court answered the question in affirmative in favor of assessee respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessee is entitled to relief granted by the Notification referred to above ? The High Court answered the referred question in the affirmative, i.e., in favor of the assessee respondent.

facts.text: Commissioner of income-tax, Bombay obtained special leave under article 136 to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate of fitness for appeal to this court, the Commissioner of income-tax, Bombay, applied for and obtained from this court special leave under article 136 of the Constitution to appeal to this court.

facts.text: Supreme Court answered the referred question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above the referred question in our option be answered in the negative.

facts.text: Commission was calculated at a given percentage of the total turnover of the year, not determined with reference to the profits.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first condition it is clear that the commission had number determined with reference to the profits of the business of the firm, for it was agreed to be calculated at a given percentage of the total turnover of the year.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exemption from tax on sums like commission disallowed to payer but taxed in its hands

anchor.surface_text: The said notification was expressed in the terms following The following classes of income shall be exempt from the tax payable under the said Act, but shall be taken into account in determining the total income of an assessee for the purposes of said Act Sums received by an assessee on account of salary, bonus, commission or other remuneration for services rendered or in lieu of interest on money advanced to a person for the purposes of his business, Where such sums have been paid out of, or determined with reference to, the profits of such business and by reason of such modes of payment or determination, have not been allowed as a deduction but have been included in the profits of the business on which income-tax has been assessed and charged under the head business.
